item.title: The Great Havana Syndrome Mystery
item.description: This summer, at least two US officials at the US Embassy in Germany felt so sick they couldn’t work. In the years since, reported Havana syndrome cases among US foreign officers have popped up in Moscow, China, London, Virginia, and, most recently, Vienna and Germany.  One recent victim, who was working at a US embassy in Europe, told the WSJ it was “striking” that some people hit with the attacks were working on Russia-related issues.  Turns out, they were suffering from an illness experienced by dozens of US diplomats and intelligence officers around the globe in recent years: Havana Syndrome.

item.title: Let the Pandemic Take Office Dress Codes
item.description: “ Most straight-sized folks can go out to a store and just buy clothing or can go thrift a lot of their professional attire,” they said. Melinda, a new teacher who asked to be identified by only their first name, spent $600+ when they switched schools after their first year of teaching and had to match a new school’s muddy “business professional” dress code. Business casual is a dress code so ill-defined that the best way to describe it is to say what it isn’t. Dress codes create financial barriers for young people, support bias in the workplace, and cause more problems that bleed over into our everyday lives, even after the end of the work day. At one point, I even got a comment from my office manager asking if I had already worn one of those three shirts earlier that week,” he said. Her job is asking employees to come back into the office, and when she tried to bring up her financial concerns about purchasing new office clothes, she was met with congratulations on her weight loss. For the last year-and-a-half, most office workers have been working from home in, at their fanciest, a stain-free shirt for meetings. Dress codes create a barrierThis confusion can be frustrating and expensive for young people entering the workforce.  And for many young professionals, there’s a serious disconnect between dress codes and pay. brands might be seeing the error of their ways. Emily Milligan, a recent grad, told Morning Brew that after getting a competitive unpaid internship with their state’s attorney general, they had to buy an entire suit. The good news: Business casual and its precious lil $50 flowy-sleeved blouses are already on their way out. Before we do, let’s officially retire office dress codes.
